content.description:
Blue Gold is an integral route that joins 'Brown Sugar' to 'Nasty Habits'.
Climb 'Brown Sugar' to the top of the sickle and then traverse left (bolts) to join 'Nasty Habits'. Follow 'Nasty Habits' until below the headwall. Climb the headwall directly.

Start this route as you would for 'Brown Sugar'.
Cams to 3" and nuts

Find your way through the lower slabs to the base of a prominent sickle (3 pitches). Either traverse to the left or follow the sickle into a groove. Follow this to a tree belay. Climb the short wall on the the left to a chimney/groove and the top (poor protection).

Route is #207 n the Lower Wall topo
Cams to 3" + set of nuts

The Donkey climbs cracks, chimneys and ledges up the eastern edge of the Great Wall. The technical climbing pitches are short and the ledge climbing follows long sections of trees and slabs. It’s a fast way to the summit from the car (6 hours on the first ascent, 9 car-to-car). The summit is 900 metres above the road. The route follows roughly 20 pitched-out pitches, but the first ascent team simul-climbing the easier terrain. The number of pitches will vary depending on the climbers. The rock is loose and it climbs more like an alpine trad route than a modern bolted multi-pitch. The north gully descent is hard to find with no trail. The first ascent team left a cairn on a ledge high up, but left no gear on the route.  Approach: Park at the base of the Great Wall and approach as for the Apron. Follow it up and right along scree and bushwhacking to the eastern edge below a large gully. Start at a big tree below two cracks.   Route: Up the left crack, loose and blocky (5.7) to below the gully. Up the gully and move right onto a treed ledge below a seam (5.8, a knifeblade would help here). Up the ramps above, finding the line of weakness. Stay left on the prow (pitch 5 on topo) and up loose and blocky bulges to upper trees. Follow ledges to the base of a buttress and chimney (5.8 good gear, pitch 8 on the topo). Up the buttress through trees to upper ledges. Move left, staying right of obvious corner crack (pitch 12) on easier terrain. At a treed junction, go up and right on steeper but solid rock (5.6). Cross scree gully up and left aiming for upper chimney (pitch 19) behind huge towers. Follow this to the summit with some 5.8 climbing through stemming sections. From the top, go west to the summit.   Descent: Follow the ridge west to the Great Gully (don’t go down here). Continue north in trees for 100-ish metres to an obvious depression west below a small sub-peak. If you can see the backside, you’ve gone too far. Head down the gully (passing some flagging tape and a cairn or two) for about an hour. At a waterfall, go up some scree then down to steep drops. Four rappels off small trees will get you to scree below. Continue down to Function Junction (sport routes) and the intersect with Dreamweaver Gully (descent for The Goat) and better trails. You could rappel from trees on The Donkey if you had some slings and two ropes. Just make sure you don’t rappel into some void by mistake.    The name: Unlike Danny’s route The Goat, which climbs techy slabs, The Donkey follows the line of least resistance from the road to the summit. If there was a donkey trail to the top, this would be it. It’s a scrappy line, more of an adventure than pure rock climbing. A few pitches have nice climbing, but the real beauty is it gets you to the summit fast. The Donkey climbs cracks, chimneys and ledges up the eastern edge of the Great Wall. The technical climbing pitches are short and the ledge climbing follows long sections of trees and slabs. It’s a fast way to the summit from the car (6 hours on the first ascent, 9 car-to-car). The summit is 900 metres above the road. The route follows roughly 20 pitched-out pitches, but the first ascent team simul-climbing the easier terrain. The number of pitches will vary depending on the climbers. The rock is loose and it climbs more like an alpine trad route than a modern bolted multi-pitch. The north gully descent is hard to find with no trail. The first ascent team left a cairn on a ledge high up, but left no gear on the route.
 
Approach: Park at the base of the Great Wall and approach as for the Apron. Follow it up and right along scree and bushwhacking to the eastern edge below a large gully. Start at a big tree below two cracks. Standard Rack

Follow a line of solution pockets to a short, steep slab followed by a mantle and the belay (2 bolts). Climb the slab to a belay at the base of a corner. Follow this to the top.

The route begins 15m up and right of the beginning of the 5th pitch of 'Where's The Remote'.
Cams to 3", set of nuts

Climb the slab to the 2nd belay of Entropy Slab.

This route is located up and right of Entropy Slab.
Bolts

climbs.name: Flashback (224)
climbs.fa: Garry Brace, Gord Clay, Dave Loucks -1981

content.description:
Follow bolts up the slab (10c) to the first belay. Trend up and left to the groove of Brown Sugar. Follow this to the tree belay on Sisyphus. Climb the bolted slab (11b) above the belay, trending right to the last belay stance of Sisyphus.

The route starts half way up the 3rd class ramp between Brown Sugar and Sisyphus.
Bolts + cams & nuts to 3"

Follow the obvious line of bolts.

Gateway is a striking slab located at the far right-hand end of the crag.
Bolts

Loon Slab has three routes on it. From left to right these are: Loonlanding (5.9), Loonwalk (5.10a), and Loontoon (5.7).

Loon Slab is approximately 150 ft. right of 'Where's The Remote'.
Bolts

Climb the slab (bolts) to the left of the 3rd pitch of Brown Sugar. From the belay climb easy but run-out 5th class climbing to the top.

Route is #223 on the Lower Wall topo
bolts+ standard trad rack

Navigate crux start and roof to easy finish! 



Right of wheres my remote 

Fixed

climbs.name: Sans Souci (235)
climbs.fa: Garry Brace, John Knight, Brian Palmer - 1976

content.description:
Climb a left-facing corner to a belay at  dead tree. Climb the left edge of the slab above to a tree ledge and belay. Climb the next slab directly, heading for a small juniper at the top-centre of the slab.

Sans Souci is located approximately 30 ft. right of Loon Slab.
Cams to 2", full set of nuts

Short bouldery route, few crux moves on slab 



Route is between time gentleman time and wheres my remote

Fixed

Use any of the lower slab routes to gain the 3rd class ramp below Brown Sugar. Follow this up and right to a tree belay at the base of a left-facing sickle/corner. Follow this feature to a good ledge and another tree belay. The final pitch traverses right and then up to a left-facing corner.


The route is located on the Lower Wall. An easy to follow trail starts on the north side of the highway behind a speed limit sign below the wall. The trail leads you directly to the Lower Wall in about 15mins. Turn climbers right past a few single pitch routes on a slab and you are staring at the start of Sisyphus. 

The start is in a corner ramp 30m uphill and left of Where's The Remote pitch 1 arete. 

Cams and nuts to 4". The route can be rapped with one 60m rope.

Head right from the Sisyphus belay tree and climb the slab (past an old bolt) to a short,steep wall, left-facing corner, and overhang. Climb to the top of a flake and move right to a belay by a juniper. Follow a crack system up a steep wall to an overlap and the final slab.

Starts at the belay tree at the base of the 4th pitch of Sisyphus.
Cams & nuts to 3"

Fun technical climbing with some fun crux sequences. 



Bolted route lookers left of gateway 

Fixed

Climb a bushy left-facing corner to a tree belay. Exit out of the corner to the right and climb flakes/slab to another tree belay (to the right of the single belay bolt for the 5th pitch of 'Where's The Remote'). Follow the left-facing corner to a small tree and a belay on top of a detached block. Climb directly up to a bolt at the base of a small, left-facing corner. Follow this corner to an obvious overhang which is turned on the right to the top.

This route starts in the bushy corner approximately 10m right of 'Where's The Remote".
Cams to 3", set of nuts

UPDATE: Alternative rap route has been installed as of 28 July, 2019. See below for updated descent. Marble Canyon is a limestone crag.  Due to the nature of the geology, loose rock and the occasional rock fall should be expected. Climbers should be mindful of this characteristic when sharing the route with other parties, especially when rappelling. Try to tread lightly.  It is normal for some holds to break in the beginning of a new route's lifecycle.  In particular, Marble Canyon has a lot of small rock debris on ledges that loom over routes. During high winds or after heavy rainfall, debris is dislodged and is prone to falling. Water-saturated gravel from the large terrace above (below the Main Wall) can create mini debris flows over the lower wall. Thankfully, the climate in this region is typically arid and sunny most of the year so rainfall is limited.   Pitch 1, 5.8: Start 50m down and right of Sisyphus on a bolted arete. Climb the arete (stay on arete) past 6 bolts to a two-bolt anchor on a small ledge. 22m, 6 bolts. UPDATE: 3 new bolted routes have been added to the wall left and right of the arete start (5.9-10b). Pitch 2, 4th: Scramble up a 4th class slab to another two-bolt anchor on the wall beside a large, coniferous tree. 15m, no bolts.  Pitch 3, 5.7: Begin left of anchor. Climb up to first bolt, then diagonally up right to the arete. Follow the arete up to a ledge with a dead tree and two-bolt anchor. 22m, 6 bolts. Option: link pitch 2 into pitch 3. Use some long slings to avoid rope drag. (40m, 6 bolts) Pitch 4, 5.9: Step right from belay, then climb upward to the arete passing two bolts. At the steep wall, clip a high bolt on the left and reach for a jug. Pull up onto the face, then step gingerly left to the arete. Follow the arete past a tree with a cordalette to a two-bolt anchor. 35m, 8 bolts. Move belay 15m up and left on the terrace to a single bolt belay at the bottom of the slab. Pitch 5, 5.7: Climb straight up the pocketed slab to a two-bolt anchor. 35m, 8 bolts. Pitch 6, 5.6: Traverse right past a high bolt n the wall to a left-facing corner. Climb up the corner, trending right past three bolts to a good ledge with a two-bolt anchor. 20m, 4 bolts. Option: link pitch 5 and pitch 6. (55m, 12 bolts) Pitch 7, 5.10a: Climb up and right from the belay to a bolt. Follow bolts as they meander up though interesting features to a two-bolt anchor on a ledge. 40m, 13 bolts. Pitch 8, 5.9: Climb up directly above anchor into a groove. Trend leftward along a crack feature up to a small, overhanging bulge. Pull left over the bottom of the bulge, then up to the arete. Follow arete diagonally rightward to two-bolt anchor. 35m, 11 bolts. Rappel the route from here or continue to the large, treed terrace. A tree on the right with a cordalette will allow you to get back to the last bolted anchor. Note: you can rappel the route from any pitch with a 60m rope. To prevent knocking rocks on any climbers below, use the alternative rap route installed:

From the top of pitch 8, rap straight down to the anchor on the top of pitch 7. From here, rap slightly skier’s right to a separate rap anchor on the wall at a small ledge. Rap to the top of pitch 5. Rap skier’s left from the top of pitch 5 to make it to the mid-route terrace (careful, it’s a rope-stretcher). From the mid-route, treed terrace find the rap anchor on the wall skiers left of the top of pitch 4. Rap straight down 4 times using bolted rap rings on the slab. On the third rap, go over a steep wall skiers right to find the last bolt anchor on the slab below.

To rap from the bottom pitches (up to the first tree with a cordalette), rappel straight down the arete to the top of pitch 2. From the anchors at the bottom of pitch 2, you can rap skiers right to a small ledge ~1m above the ground (careful, it's a rope-stretcher) Marble Canyon on the lower wall. Approach: Park at the gravel pullout on the lake side of the highway ~2kms north-west of the BC Parks Marble Canyon campsite (on Crown Lake). Cross the highway and follow a well-defined trail in front of a “littering fine” sign for 15 minutes up to the wall (turns into a scree-slope). Head climber’s right along base of wall, 50m down and right, passing the start of Sisyphus to a bolted arete behind a large tree. Stay on the arete, climbing to a 2-bolt anchor above. 13 Draws, 60m rope.

Mantel up to ledge, follow slab and crimps with a few little tougher sections to easy top out. 



Right of Paparazzi,

Fixed
